comments.body:
May be worth setting JAVA_HOME. I'm not sure what happens if you run a djk11 binary with JAVA_HOME pointing to jdk8. (Which might be the case here? I'm not sure who/what sets JAVA_HOME for the rest of our build.)
```
export JAVA_HOME=$(realpath $(dirname $(rlocation jdk11_nix/bin/java))/..)
```
should work I think.
hm, I thought JAVA_HOME doesnâ€™t matter if you invoke the binary directly but maybe Iâ€™m wrong.

Looking through https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2025290/what-is-java-home-how-does-the-jvm-find-the-javac-path-stored-in-java-home, the JVM itself does not care about it at all. Itâ€™s used by other stuff to find java which doesnâ€™t matter if we already invoke java.

It's also sometimes used to find bits of java other than the executable. I'm not concerned about it not being set, as the failures modes for that are well understood (non-zero exit), but I am a little bit concerned about what happens if it is set but to a different JDK than the executable you're running.

It's likely we're not using anything that uses it, though. It's mostly used by "old" programs like Java IDEs and the like.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +8,12 @@
# Canton has some issues with JDK8 so we run it with JDK11.
JAVA="$(rlocation jdk11_nix/bin/java)"

CANTON_COMMAND=(

comments.body: Well, that's nice and easy. ðŸ˜€

Note we don't have any test involving more than two participants and by default the test tool will pick the participants in the same order as they are presented. You can use `--shuffle-participants` to make sure other participants are picked. This only ensures (to a certain degree, given the randomness) that all participants are used as part of the tests, note that currently there is no test that uses more than two participants in a given test.

I noticed one lonely `TransactionServiceIT.TXTreeBlinding` test with a third `delta` participant. I had been contemplating `--shuffle-participants`, but was a bit concerned about introducing flakiness. In a separate PR, and perhaps in the Canton repo first, I will give this a try.
